message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest the patient has cellulitis, which is most commonly caused by Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus. None of the other options are commonly associated with cellulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infected wound and symptoms of fever, chills, and lymphadenopathy suggest a bacterial infection. Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common cause of cellulitis, which is the most likely diagnosis based on the physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a bacterial infection, and among the options, Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common cause of cellulitis, especially in cases where there is a break in the skin. A history of injury to the finger indicates a possible entry point for bacterial infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infected wound, red streaks, and swollen lymph nodes suggest the patient has cellulitis. Among the options, Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common microorganism known to cause cellulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that he has developed cellulitis and lymphangitis. Among the options, Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common cause of this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including an infected wound, red streaks, and lymphadenopathy, suggest cellulitis. Among the microorganisms listed, Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common cause of cellulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infected wound, red streaks on the forearm, and painful lymphadenopathy point to a diagnosis of lymphangitis. Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common organism responsible for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest cellulitis with lymphangitis, which is commonly caused by Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus. Staphylococcus aureus can also cause cellulitis, but Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common cause. The other options are less common causes of cellulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of an infected wound and subcutaneous red streaks on the ventral surface of the right forearm, along with painful lymphadenopathy suggests a diagnosis of acute lymphangitis, which is often caused by Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus. The other microorganisms listed may also cause infections but are less commonly associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presenting symptoms suggest cellulitis, and among the options, Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common microorganism known to cause cellulitis. Aeromonas hydrophila and Pseudomonas aeruginosa are more commonly associated with wounds contaminated with dirty water, and Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of skin and soft tissue infections but is less common in cellulitis.
